author: NEW YORK DAILY NEWS
title: De Blasio plan would fix Pier 40, build affordable housing
text:
Anthony DelMundo/New York Daily News "This is a tremendous opportunity to save Pier 40 and to build the permanently affordable housing this community so badly needs,” Mayor de Blasio said. The de Blasio administration and City Councilman Corey Johnson Thursday announced a plan to transform a dingy three-block stretch in the West Village into a five building housing complex — and generate $100 million for rundown Pier 40.
The deal, which must be approved by the Hudson River Park Trust and the City Council, allows the aging and badly damaged pier to transfer its development rights to the other site, which is located across the West Side Highway.
That site, currently known as St. John’s Center, covers more than three city blocks from Charlton to Clarkson Streets near the West Side Highway.
The developers will turn that site into a 1,587 unit complex with five buildings.
The tallest of those buildings will be 40 stories high.
The group, known as St. John’s Partners and which includes Westbrook Partners and Atlas Capital Group LLC, has promised that nearly 500 of the housing units at the new complex will be affordable, with an emphasis on senior housing.
nyc.gov The transaction, which will undergo a full public review process, would generate about $100 million to repair Pier 40 by transferring development rights to the nearby St. John’s site, located across the West Side Highway from Pier 40. Enlarge nyc.gov The developers will turn that site into a 1,587 unit complex with five buildings, with 500 of the units dedicated to affordable housing. Enlarge The developers will turn the site into a 1,587 unit complex with five buildings, with 500 of the units dedicated to affordable housing.
"This is a tremendous opportunity to save Pier 40 and to build the permanently affordable housing this community so badly needs,” Mayor de Blasio said.
The $100 million that the developers agreed to pay will go toward funding repairs for Pier 40, which is so dilapidated that parts of it have been closed as a safety precaution.
Johnson, who is the city councilman who reps the West Village, praised the plan.
“At long last, we have a great plan that would address the urgent situation at the Pier and give this community treasure back to local families,” said Johnson.
His approval is key because the Council must approve big land transfers like this, and rarely votes to approve unless the Council member who reps the area backs the deal.
